subclusters.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial ROS Hormesis and Signaling Theory

theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on ROS generated by aerobic metabolism (flight activity) causing oxidative damage to biomolecules and aging.
Emphasizes ROS accumulation from metabolism, decline of antioxidant enzymes (SOD, catalase), and oxidative damage driving aging.
Describes ROS from aerobic respiration causing cumulative damage; includes neurolipofuscin as oxidative damage biomarker.
Focuses on mitochondrial ROS generation, Coenzyme Q's role in modulating ROS, and mitochondrial oxidative damage accelerating aging.
Describes cumulative ROS damage causing aging and age-related diseases, with antioxidant defenses regulating ROS levels.
Focuses on mitochondrial ROS production damaging proteins and membranes, with antioxidant enzymes modulating aging.
ROS accumulation causes oxidative damage to biomolecules; antioxidant enzymes mitigate damage and promote healthy aging.
Highlights mitochondrial electron transport chain as main ROS source causing oxidative damage and aging.
Aging driven by ROS damage accumulation from metabolism; antioxidant enzymes modulate oxidative damage.
ROS accumulation causes molecular damage; antioxidant defense system influences aging rate.
Oxidative damage accumulation and antioxidant defense differences explain sex differences in oxidative stress resistance and longevity.
Mitochondrial dysfunction increases ROS production causing oxidative damage and age-related kidney pathologies.
Lower mitochondrial ROS generation and oxidative damage correlate with increased longevity across species.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial ROS Hormesis and Signaling Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Proposes dual role of mitochondrial ROS: damaging at high levels but lifespan-extending via reverse electron transport signaling at moderate levels.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial ROS Hormesis and Signaling Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Mitochondrial complex I inhibition causes transient ROS burst that acts as hormetic signal activating adaptive stress responses.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial ROS Hormesis and Signaling Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Moderate ROS induce protective transcriptional programs via hormesis, extending lifespan; high glucose suppresses this hormesis.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial ROS Hormesis and Signaling Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Mitochondrial ROS at low/moderate levels act as signaling molecules triggering hormetic stress responses that extend lifespan.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial ROS Hormesis and Signaling Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Resistance to oxidative and multiplex stresses linked to lifespan extension; antioxidant compounds mimic stress response pathways.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial ROS Hormesis and Signaling Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: ROS act as signaling molecules regulating intestinal stem cell function and aging via multiple pathways and metabolic adaptations.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial ROS Hormesis and Signaling Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Oxidative stress drives aging; DAF-16/FOXO transcription factor modulates antioxidant defenses and lifespan.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial ROS Hormesis and Signaling Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: ROS accumulation activates Ras/PKA signaling via intracellular acidification, linking oxidative stress to aging regulation.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial ROS Hormesis and Signaling Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Modulation of Coenzyme Q biosynthesis affects mitochondrial ROS production and lifespan, linking mitochondrial metabolism to aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial ROS Hormesis and Signaling Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Oxygen sensing neurons and neuropeptide signaling interact with hypoxia and insulin pathways to regulate lifespan via ROS-related signaling.
Focuses on thioredoxin system as key antioxidant defense whose decline with age increases oxidative damage and accelerates aging.
SKN-1/Nrf transcription factor regulates antioxidant gene expression; activation enhances oxidative stress resistance and lifespan.
SKN-1/Nrf2 pathway activation by oxidative stress promotes antioxidant defenses and neuroprotection, contributing to longevity.
Peroxisomal catalase deficiency leads to increased ROS and accelerated aging, highlighting importance of antioxidant enzymes.
Methionine sulfoxide reductase system repairs oxidized proteins, protecting cells from oxidative damage and influencing aging.
Oxidative stress impairs proteasome function in T cells, reducing degradation of damaged proteins and contributing to immune aging.
8-oxoG oxidative DNA lesion has hormetic effects; regulated repair balances oxidative stress defense and gene expression.
Reactive species cause oxidative damage; antioxidant defenses are complex and imperfect, with redox signaling playing key roles.
